turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I've been re-reading Arsonist's Daughter. It's so beautiful, Grady. So natural. It's like all your sentences always existed, just waiting around in Style Heaven, or wherever, for you to fetch them down.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I thank you.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: And I love the inscription you wrote to me. Only I'm not quite the downy innocent you think I am.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I hope that isn't true. We need all the downy innocents we can get.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: So what are you going to do?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Do?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I just mean, I -- I guess Emily isn't going to be there when you get home.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Look, Hannah. When you get him home... make sure he's all right. Before you leave. Okay?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I would if I knew where I was taking him.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hannah, are you telling me you don't know where James Leer lives?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Some apartment somewhere. But I've never seen it.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That strikes me as odd.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: James is odd. I know he has an aunt in Sewickley Heights. I dropped him there once, but...  Come to think of it, it wasn't even his Aunt's house. He said she worked there. Or something. I don't remember.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: His bag. You know that ratty green thing he's always carrying around. He must've left it inside.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hh-uh. Last time I saw it was...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: All right. Take him to my place. He can crash on the sofa.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: The one in your office? It's the best one for naps.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't think it really matters, Hannah. We could probably stand him up in the garage with the snow shovels at this point.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I thought we were going to talk. Last night.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh. Well. I...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Grady!

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I know I shouldn't have, but there it was, just sort of lying out, and I couldn't resist and -- and -- I suck.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No, it's okay. I just can't believe I left it out in the open like that. Crabtree hasn't been in here, has he? Poking around?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I don't know -- maybe -- I don't think so.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Listen, Hannah. You don't remember where that aunt worked, do you? James' aunt.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: He shot the Chancellor's dog, didn't he? The blind one.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Actually, He's not the Chancellor's -- What?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: At first the police thought he just ran away, but this afternoon Dr. Gaskell found some blood spots on the carpet --

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Crabtree said it sounded like something James would be messed up in.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Crabtree? He doesn't even know James.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Who does?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: The aunt, Hannah. Where did you take James that day?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I told you, Sewickly Heights.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: But where? I need the street.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I don't know, Grady. I just dropped him on a corner.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: He cribbed that from Borges.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: It beats 'What's your major?'

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Right. Anyway, I was wondering if I could borrow your car. Mine's sort of out of commission.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Sure. The keys are on the dresser next to... to your book.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I uh, I didn't finish, I... fell asleep.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That good, huh?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: No, it's not that, it's...

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: It's just that, you know, I was thinking about how, in class, you're always telling us 'that writers make choices -- at least the good ones. And, don't get me wrong. I'm not saying the book isn't really great -- I mean, really great -- but at times it's, well, very detailed, you know, with the genealogies of everyone's horses and all the dental records and so on -- and I don't know, maybe I'm wrong, but it sort of reads, in places, like, well, actually, like...  ...you didn't make any choices at all. And I was wondering if it might not be different if, maybe, when you wrote, you weren't always... under the influence.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Uh huh. Well, thanks for the thought, but, as shocking as this may sound, I'm not the first writer to sip a little weed. And furthermore, it might interest you to know that one book I wrote, as you say, 'under the influence,' happened to win a little something called the PEN award which, by the way, I accepted 'under the influence.'

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Professor Tripp.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Chancellor.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I got the message you called.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I got the message you called too.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Easy there.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I'm sorry. It's these goddamned shoes. I don't know how anyone actually walks in these things.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I need to talk to you.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: That's funny. I need to talk to you, too.  Perhaps you could put some of these coats in the upstairs guest room, Professor Tripp.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't believe I know where the upstairs guest room is.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Well then. I'd better show you. Terry --

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: New?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Walter just got it back from the framer today.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: You go first.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: All right. This morning --

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I'm pregnant.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Well. This is... surprising. Does Walter...?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I think Walter would find this a little more than surprising.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Emily left me this morning.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: She's left before...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: She's left the room before. She always came back.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: So. I guess we just divorce our spouses, marry each other, and have this baby, right? Simple.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Simple.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Is that Cristaile?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hm.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: My God, I wear the same scent as a transvestite. She IS a transvestite, isn't: she?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: If she's not now, Terry will make sure she is by the end of the evening.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Has he asked to see the book yet?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: And? Are you going to tell him?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No. Maybe. I don't know. I don't know what I'm going to do.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Neither do I.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Sara, my arm. I'm stuck, honey.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I guess you're going to have to chew it off then.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: You had another one, didn't you? You have to see a doctor, Grady. First thing Monday morning. All right?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Is the thing -- is it over?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Almost. Want to sit up?  What's the matter?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Nothing. I think I twisted my --

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Don't. I know what you're going to say.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No, really, Sara, I don't think you --

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: You love Emily. I know that. And you need to stay with her.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't think I really have a choice in, that. Emily left me.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: She'll come back. That's why I'm going to... to not have this baby.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Not have it.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: No. There's no way. I mean, don't you think there's no way?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Well, no, I don't see any way.  And I know how hard it is for you to -- to lose this chance.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: No you don't. And fuck you for saying you do. And fuck you for "saying...  ...for saying there's just no way. Because there could be a way, Grady.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Who's gun is that?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It's -- it's a souvenir. Of Baltimore.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Heavy. Smells like gunpowder.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Caps.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Pow.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You got me.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I love you, Grady.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I can't believe you hung up on me, you dick.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Totally. I'm sorry. A lot was happening this morning. Can you talk?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Walter's on campus, being the good soldier for WordFest. But he's a basket case. Someone stole Marilyn's jacket last night. And Poe's missing, too.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I heard.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: You heard? How?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: A twelve-year-old policeman came by the house this morning.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Did you confess?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Your fingerprints were all over the bedroom.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Really? That was fast.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I'm kidding. Hello?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh. Right. Ha. Listen, about last night. There is something I need to tell...

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Are you limping? Why are you limping?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Hub? Oh, well, that's part of what I need to...

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Did you pass out again, Grady? Did you fall somewhere?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No. I mean. Well, actually, yes. Sort of. I don't remember. Listen, Sara, I have to tell you something.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Gee, Grady, that sounded so heartfelt. I don't know whether to swoon or smirk.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Really, Sara, I...

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I believe you. I believe you want to be with me. But this is not just about me anymore.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I know that. I know what's at stake here...

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: No, I don't think you do. And besides... I haven't decided yet.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: About the baby.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: That... and you.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Who's that sitting in your car?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: James Leer.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: What's he doing out there?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm sort of helping him work through some issues.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Sara.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I tried to call, but apparently there's something wrong...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: It seems one of our students is -- missing and his parents found a dead dog in his bed.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm sorry, Sara. I've been trying to tell you. It's all my --

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I'm not very happy with you right now, Grady. But more importantly, Walter's not very happy and he's gotten the police involved. They seem to think James Leer is somehow responsible for all of this. You wouldn't happen to know where James is, would you, Grady?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Inside.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: And the jacket?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Over there. In the backseat of the...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Someone stole my car.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Grady.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Honestly. Someone stole my car. I parked it right there last night.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Are you sure you parked it there?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Of course, I'm sure. Ah, Christ, the puberty police are back.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: This is not what the university has in mind when it promises a liberal education, Grady.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Would Walter really press charges?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: It's within the realm. He takes his souvenirs pretty seriously. And he was just a wee bit prickly this morning.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: You didn't happen to call the house last night, did you, Grady?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I think I might have.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: And what do you think you might have said?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I think I might've said I was in love with you.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: He told you.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: He told me.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: And what did you say?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I said it didn't sound like you.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm so glad to see you, Sara.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I believe you. Did that nice doctor let you out? Or is this you improvising again, Grady?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm through improvising.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Terry told me about Wonder Boys. Is it true? Did you lose it all?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I lost it all.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Oh, Grady. You're such a putz.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: And you're old.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Ouch. How many?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Dozens. It's very sad.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I went and looked at some babies just now.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I guess you have to go on faith.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Some times...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Did you tell Walter?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I told Walter.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Does he still love you?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: It didn't come up.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Did you just make that up?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: In the hospital. I was kind of excited about it at the time, but then I was on pretty heavy painkillers.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: You don't deserve me, you know.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I know, but sometimes...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: The more the merrier.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: Terry was telling me about you on the plane. It was all so interesting.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That perfume you're wearing, Antonia. It wouldn't happen to be Cristaile, would it?

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: Why yes. How did you know?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Lucky guess.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: That's a nice greenhouse.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It's Mrs. Gaskell's. Her hobby.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: Who's he barking at now?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: He's still barking at me. He's blind.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: I need a ride.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm your man.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: Couldn't he have just thrown a shoe at the poor thing?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: James is... I don't know...

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: Disturbed. And when your friend Crabtree gets done with him, he's going to be even more disturbed.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm not sure that's possible.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: Sure it is.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Listen, Antonia --

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: Tony. Now that I'm home.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Tony. I'm sorry if things didn't work out so well for you tonight. With Terry.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: Forget it. I should've known better. Your friend is just, I don't know, into collecting weird tricks. Mind?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: He's writing his name in water.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Like most editors, he really wants to be a writer, but he's too busy living a novel to bother writing one.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: That sounds like a fancy excuse for being a shit.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: He'd call it habit. But now... I get the feeling he's going through the motions a bit.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: You mean because his career's ruined and all?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Jesus. Is that what he told you?

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: He said he hasn't had a success in ten years and everyone in New York thinks he's kind of a...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That's nice. All we have is a Japanese beetle trap.

turns.speaker: MISS SLOVIAK
turns.text: It's a bathtub. What she's standing under.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Walter?

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: Who's this ?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: It's Grady, Walter.

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: Grady?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: GRADY Tripp. English Department.

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: I know it's you, Grady, I just... Christ, Grady, do you know what time it is?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I have... eight-fifteen. That's not right, is it?

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: It's three-thirty, Grady.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: This is important.

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: What is it, Grady?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm in love with your wife.

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Sara. I'm in love with her.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WALTER'S VOICE
turns.text: Nevertheless, I'd like to see you in my office Monday morning.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: No. I guess you're here for the backpack.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh... yeah.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Is it good?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I don't know. It might be...

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Say, Professor Tripp, is all that stuff true about Errol Flynn? How he used to put coke on his dick. To make himself, you know, like, last longer?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Christ, Traxler. How the hell should I know?

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Well, jeez, you're reading his biography, aren't you?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh, right. Yeah, that's true. He used to rub all kinds of things on it. Paprika. Ground lamb.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Sick.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Who's that guy?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Her husband.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: What exactly are we doing here, Professor Tripp?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Taking the long way home.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yo, Traxler.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Hey, Professor Tripp.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Do you get high, Sam?

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Only when I'm working.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Holy shit. Are you serious?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: As a heart attack.

turns.speaker: TRAXLER
turns.text: Thanks -- Whoa, Professor Tripp, careful here...

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Yes. He's a good kid. Maybe a little messed up.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Well, I'm sure with the proper guidance he'll be fine.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: What made you pull out that old thing?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: I was thinking of you.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: It's no Arsonist's Daughter, but I guess you know that. It's a young man's book. It got me remembering how it felt to be young.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Maybe I should read it.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Oh, I don't think there's any danger of you aging prematurely, Grady.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Where's Emily, Hank?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: I don't know if she'd want me to tell you that, Grady.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I'm not going to stalk her. Hank. I just... want to know where I stand.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Where you stand?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I -- just want to say I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: She's in Philadelphia seeing Linda Aahby. The neurologist.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Neurologist? Why? What's wrong?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Nothing's wrong. They went to Wellesley together.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Oh. Right. Linda... I haven't been doing a lot of sleeping lately. My editor's in town and I have the book to finish and --

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Ah, right. The book.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Listen, Hank, I'm sorry about all this. I didn't come here to upset you and Irene. I want you to know that.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Why did you come here, Grady?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I -- just wanted to see her, I guess -- Emily. And to see you too -- you and Irene. And to let everyone know that, even though it may be difficult to comprehend now, this -- everything that's happening -- it's not forever. It doesn't mean "Goodbye."

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Give me a break, Grady.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Well, there's always people you don't know at these things, but I can't say there was anybody particularly suspicious... Wait. There was one guy. Tiny fella. Claimed to be a jockey.

turns.speaker: OFFICER PUPCIK
turns.text: A jockey? You mean, like --

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Horses, right. Vernon something...  Hardapple.

turns.speaker: OFFICER PUPCIK
turns.text: Hardapple?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I could be wrong. What happened anyway?

turns.speaker: OFFICER PUPCIK
turns.text: Huh? Oh, someone pulled a B&E on Dr. Gaskell's closet. And the dog's missing.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: That's weird.

turns.speaker: OFFICER PUPCIK
turns.text: We figure the perpetrator let him out. He's blind and we figure he just wandered off and got run over.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: The perpetrator.

turns.speaker: OFFICER PUPCIK
turns.text: No, the dog.

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: Just kidding.

turns.speaker: OFFICER PUPCIK
turns.text: One other thing. About this kid, this student of yours -- Leer -- James Leer. You wouldn't know how I could get in touch with him, would you?

turns.speaker: GRADY
turns.text: I might have his number on campus.

turns.speaker: OFFICER PUPCIK
turns.text: That's all right. We'll find him.

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Are you riding with me, James?

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: No, I'm going ho --

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: George Sanders?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Mr. Crabtree was saying how George Sanders killed himself, only he couldn't remember how.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Pills. August 25, 1972. In a Costa Brava hotel room.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: There's so many...

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: Just a few then. The big ones.

turns.speaker: JAMES LEER
turns.text: Pier Angeli, 1971 or '72, also pills. Charles Boyer, 1978, pills again. Charles Butterworth, 1946, I think. In a car. Supposedly it was an accident, but, you know...  He was distraught. Dorothy Dandridge, she took pills in, like, 1965. Albert Dekker, 1968, he hung himself. He wrote his suicide note in lipstick on his stomach. Alan Ladd, '64, more pills, Carole Landis, pills again, I forget when. George Reeves, Superman on TV, shot himself. Jean Seberg, pills of course, 1979. Everett Sioane -- he was good -- pills. Margaret Sullavan, pills, Lupe Velez, a lot of pills. Gig Young. He shot himself and his wife in 1978. There are more but I don't know if you would have heard of them. Ross Alexander? Clara Blandick? Maggie McNamara? Gia Scaia?

turns.speaker: HANNAH GREEN
turns.text: I haven't heard of half of those.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I could swear I had a '63 Chateau Latour in here. You haven't seen it, have you?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I doubt I'd recognize a '63 Chateau Latour if I was sitting on it.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You'd recognize it if you tasted it.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: I doubt it, darling.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Well, Q certainly will. And, given that he will be addressing 500 people in little over an hour...

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: You want to keep him happy.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: If he's happy...  I'm happy.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Don't need to think fast to handle beer.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Took some talking to convince your super I was a relative.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I told her all my relatives are good- looking.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: You look good, damn good, considering you're an old man now!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Seems like the whole world's gotten younger.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: You doing okay?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Got a job at old Frank's place. His son runs it now.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Oh man, that kid takes himself real serious.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yeah, you still with Northland?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Foreman now.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: No shit.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Five years.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Beautiful. How's business?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Booming. Lots of building going on. We can't keep up with all the work. In fact, I just hired a few new guys...

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I'll never forget you got me started there.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I just recommended you. You still had to prove yourself.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Hey, is that a school?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: K through sixth.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Living across the street from a grade school. Jesus.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Something wrong with that?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I was just thinking of... the noise.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I like the noise.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: One hundred and twenty feet.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Law says I can't come within one hundred feet of where children congregate. I figure the distance from my window to the school is one hundred and twenty. Make a bet?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: No way, man, you'd rob me blind!

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: But maybe it's not so healthy being so close, you know, to a school.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You find me a decent place for under three hundred a month in this town, and I'll happily move out of this crap neighborhood.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I should go. Your sister worries, and when she worries she yells.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: How is she?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Annette? She's good... tense.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: When can I see her?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I'm working on it.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Is it because of Anna?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I don't know. She won't talk about it.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You're the only one in the family who still talks to me.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I remember when they all referred to me as "the little spic poor Annette married." Except her brother. You treated me with respect.  Look, you paid your dues. Your slate is clean now.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: How old is Anna?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: She'll be twelve next week. We're throwing a big party on Saturday. Wish I could ask you to come...

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Only if it's no closer than a hundred feet.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: This little table is one heavy bitch.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Cherry.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: It's made from cherry. That's a hard wood.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: It's a nice table.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Notice the grain. See how deep and rich the red runs?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Yeah. It's really nice.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: It's my own design. You won't find another table like it in the world.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: It was a beautiful present.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Then why the fuck are you giving it back to me?!

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: You need a table.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: She was going to throw it out, wasn't she? Just toss it like a scrap of wood.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: It wasn't like that.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Then what? What?!

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: She's got all this new furniture now. She said it didn't fit anymore, so I kept it in the attic. I thought you might like it.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I made that table for you and Annette, for your wedding. I put a lot of love into it.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I know, man. I love this table too.  But I also love my wife.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: What's happening?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Mariners are pounding the shit out of the Tigers.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Fucking Mariners.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Fucking Tigers. They got no pitching except for a bunch of green kids straight out of Double A or Southern Cal.  How was the party?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: What party?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: The birthday party.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Oh, Anna's. It was great, man. Anna was so pretty.  She looked like a princess, like one of those girls in a fairy tale, you know, like Snow White.
